sen.j: 稲荷神を祀る神社を稲荷神社（いなりじんじゃ）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Shrines that worship the god Inari are called Inari-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: また京都市伏見区にある伏見稲荷大社が日本各所にある神道上の稲荷神社の総本社とされている。
sen.e: Fushimi-inari-taisha Shrine in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto Prefecture is considered to be the headquarters of all the Inari-jinja Shrines across the country.
sen.cmt: 「神道上の稲荷神社」という表現が使われていますが、shrineという言葉にShintoの意味が込められているのであえて、「神道上の」という言葉は英訳からはずしました。

sen.j: 稲荷神は、ウカノミタマ（うかのみたま、倉稲魂命とも書く）などの穀物の神の総称であり、宇迦之御魂神の他、トヨウケビメ（とようけびめ）、ウケモチ（うけもち）、オオゲツヒメ（おおげつひめ）、若宇迦売神（わかうかめ）、御饌津神（みけつ）などとされている。
sen.e: The god Inari is the general term for the harvest god, which includes Ukanomitama (the god of foodstuffs), Ukanomitama-no-Mikoto (or Uganomitama), Toyokebime, Ukemochi, Ogetsuhime, Wakaukame, and Miketsu (the rice god).

The god Inari is the general term for the harvest god, which includes Ukanomitama (the god of foodstuffs), Ukanomitama-no-Mikoto (or Uganomitama), Toyokebime, Ukemochi, Ogetsuhime, Wakaukame, and Miketsu (the rice god).
The god Inari is the general term for the harvest god, which includes Ukanomitama (the god of foodstuffs), Toyoukebime, Ukemochi, Ogetsuhime, Wakaukame, and Miketsu (the rice god).
sen.cmt: "Ukanomitama"と"Ukanomitama-no-Mikoto"は同じであるため、重複部分を削除しました。Toyokebime→Toyoukebimeに修正しました。

sen.j: また神仏習合思想においては仏法における荼吉尼天が宇迦之御魂神の本地仏とされる（その総本社は豊川稲荷）。
sen.e: In the Shinbutsu shugo shiso theory (the amalgamation of Buddhism with Shinto, the Japanese indigenous religion), Buddhist Dakiniten (Dakini (fairy-goddess)) is honjibutsu (a Buddha, the true nature of a Shinto deity) of Ukanomitama-no-Mikoto (the headquarters of all the temples that worship Dakiniten is Toyokawa-inari).

In the Shinbutsu shugo shiso theory (the amalgamation of Buddhism with Shinto, the Japanese indigenous religion), Buddhist Dakiniten (Dakini - fairy-goddess) is honjibutsu (a Buddha, the true nature of a Shinto deity) of Ukanomitama-no-Mikoto (the headquarters of all the temples that worship Dakiniten is Toyokawa-inari).

In the Shinbutsu shugo shiso theory (the amalgamation of Buddhism with Shinto, the Japanese indigenous religion), Buddhist Dakiniten (Dakini - fairy-goddess) is honjibutsu (a Buddha, the true nature of a Shinto deity) of Ukanomitama no Mikoto (the headquarters of all the temples that worship Dakiniten is Toyokawa-inari).
sen.cmt: ハイフンをとり、"Ukanomitama no Mikoto"としました。

sen.j: 日本にある稲荷神社は2万社とも3万社とも言われており、屋敷神として企業のビルの屋上や工場の敷地内などに祀られているものまで入れると稲荷神を祀る社は無数と言って良いほどの数になる。
sen.e: Presumably, there are twenty or thirty thousands of Inari-jinja Shrines across the country, but if you include deities enshrined on the roof of buildings and within factory sites, which is called Yahiki-gami, the god Inari is worshipped by countless number of shrines.

sen.j: 稲荷大神は欽明天皇が即位（539年または531年）される前のまだ幼少のある日「秦（はた）の大津父（おおつち）という者を登用すれば、大人になった時にかならずや、天下をうまく治めることができる」と言う夢を見た。
sen.e: Emperor Kinmei, who ascended to throne in 539 (or 531), saw a dream when he was a child; in it, he was told that if he gave promotions to a person named "HATA no Otsuchi", he would be surely successful in ruling the country when he grew up.

sen.j: 早速方々へ使者を遣わして探し求めたことにより、和銅4年（711年）2月 (旧暦)初午の日に秦（はたの）伊呂巨（具）（いろこ（ぐ））が鎮座した。
sen.e: Soon, he started searching for the person by dispatching envoys to various places, and on the first Day of Uma (the horse, the seventh sign of Chinese zodiac) of February 711, Hata-no-Iroko (or, Irogu) appeared seated.

sen.j: 諸蕃（渡来および帰化系氏族）のうち約3分の1の多数を占める「秦氏」の項によれば、中国・秦の始皇帝13世孫、孝武王の子孫にあたる功徳王が仲哀天皇の御代に、また融通王が応神天皇の御代に、127県の秦氏を引率して朝鮮半島の百済から帰化したという記録がある。
sen.e: According to the article of "Hata Clan", who accounted for about one-third of the-then naturalized people, King Kotobuo, the descendent of Kobuo, who was thirteen generations away from the first Qin Emperor in China, came to Japan from Paekche (or Kudara) (an ancient Korean kingdom), taking with him as many as one-hundred twenty-seven prefectures of the Hata clan in the era of Emperor Chuai, and King Yudu in the era of Emperor Ojin.

sen.j: しかし、加羅（伽耶）または新羅から来たのではないかとも考えられている（新羅は古く辰韓＝秦韓と呼ばれ秦の遺民が住み着いたとの伝承がある）。
sen.e: Or they might have come from Kara or Shiragi; Shiragi is an ancient Korean kingdom, where survivors from Qin ("秦"), a Chinese dynasty, are believed to have settled as its old alias, "Shinkan" ("秦韓"), signifies "Qin-Korea".

sen.e: In 711, the Hata clan in Fukakusa (Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City) enshrined the god Inari by building a magnificent shrine in a flat place on the Inarisan-sangamine Mountain, which locates in the middle of the Kyoto-bonchi Basin.

sen.j: 深草の秦氏族は系譜の上で見る限り、太秦の秦氏族、すなわち松尾大社を祀った秦都理《はたのとり》の弟が、稲荷社を祀った秦伊呂巨（具）となっており、いわば分家と考えられていたようだ。
sen.e: According to their family tree, a younger brother of HATA no Tori, who built Matsuo-taisya Shrine, is Hata no Iroko (or Irogu), who built the Inari-jinja Shrine; this may suggest that the Hata clan of Fukakusa is a branch family of the Hata clan of Uzumaza (Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City).

sen.j: 本来穀物・農業の神とされるが自然の生育に任せ収穫した稲を荷のように架けて乾燥させるまでに生長し、その後は人手で処理できるまでに至ったことの感謝を表しているとも考えられる。
sen.e: The god Inari is considered to be the harvest and agriculture god; "Inari", which is spelled "稲荷" in Chinese characters (with "稲" meaning rice-plants and "荷" baggage), may express a sense of gratitude to Nature for making them grow to the point where farmers can reap them and hang them like baggage ("荷") to dry for harvest.

sen.j: （荷田春満は，稲荷社祠官，羽倉家の生まれで，僧契沖に始まる近世国学（和学 倭学）を発展させて，「万葉集，古事記，日本書紀」研究の基礎を作った。
sen.e: Azumamaro KADA, who was born to the Hakura family whose profession was the priest of an Inari Shrine, laid a foundation for the research of classic Japanese literature, Manyoushuu (famous 8thC poetry), Japan's oldest anthology of poems, Records of Ancient Matters (Japan's oldest historical record), and Nihon-shoki (the oldest chronicles of Japan), by developing Kinsei Kokugaku (also called "Wagaku") (the study of pre-modern Japanese literature and culture).

sen.cmt: Manyoushuu→Manyoshuに修正しました。「万葉集，古事記，日本書紀」の表現を統一させるため、文章を一部修正・変更しました。

sen.j: 門下に賀茂真淵がおり，続く本居宣長，平田篤胤と共に，国家の四大人といわれた。）

sen.j: 秦氏の祖先である伊呂具の秦公（いろぐのはたのきみ）は、富裕に驕って餅を的にした。
sen.e: IROGU no Hatanokimi, who was affluent and arrogant, tried to shoot an arrow, using a sticky rice cake as the target.

sen.j: するとその餅が白い鳥に化して山頂へ飛び去った。
sen.e: Then, the rice cake turned into a white bird and flew away to the top of a mountain.

sen.j: そこに稲が生ったので（伊弥奈利生ひき）、それが神名となった。
sen.e: There, rice-plants ("ine") ripened ("nari") and this is how the god was given its name.

sen.j: 伊呂具の秦公はその稲の元へ行き、過去の過ちを悔いて、そこの木を根ごと抜いて屋敷に植え、それを祀ったという。
sen.e: IROGU no Hatanokimi, who went over to the rice-plants, repented all the mistakes he had made in the past, pulled them up by their roots, and replanted them in his house to worshipped them.

sen.j: また、稲生り（いねなり）が転じて「イナリ」となり「稲荷」の字が宛てられた。
sen.e: "Ine-nari" (rice has ripened) changed to "inari", to which the Chinese character "稲荷" was applied.

sen.j: 都が平安京に遷都されると、元々この地を基盤としていた秦氏が政治的な力を持ち、それにより稲荷神が広く信仰されるようになった。
sen.e: When the capital was transferred to Kyoto, the Hata clan who had ruled the region gained political power, causing the worship for the god Inari to prevail.

sen.j: さらに、東寺建造の際に秦氏が稲荷山から木材を提供したことで、稲荷神は東寺の守護神とされるようになった。
sen.e: When To-ji Temple was built, the Hata clan provided lumbers from its Inari-yama Mountain, causing the god Inari to be worshipped as the guardian deity of To-ji Temple.
When To-ji Temple was built, the Hata clan provided lumber from its own Mount Inari-yama, causing the god Inari to be worshipped as the guardian deity of To-ji Temple.

sen.j: 『二十二社本縁』では空海が稲荷神と直接交渉して守護神になってもらったと書かれている。
sen.e: According to Nijunisya honroku, Kukai (a Japanese monk, scholar, poet, and artist, founder of the Shingon or "True Word" school of Buddhism) directly asked the god Inari to be his guardian deity.

sen.cmt: 『二十二社本縁』の読みの誤りを訂正、ダブルクォーテーションを入れました。Nijunisya→Nijunishaに修正しました。

sen.j: 東寺では、真言密教における荼枳尼天（だきにてん、インドの女神ダーキニー）に稲荷神を習合させ、真言宗が全国に布教されるとともに、荼枳尼天の概念も含んだ状態の稲荷信仰が全国に広まることとなった。
sen.e: At Toji Temple, The god Inari was merged to Dakiniten (an Indian female deity, Dakini) of Shingon Mikkyo (Sino-Japanese esoteric Buddhism), which helped the worship of the god Inari that had encompassed the concept of Dakiniten spread as Shingon spread across the country.

At Toji Temple, The god Inari merged with Dakiniten (an Indian female deity, Dakini) of Shingon Mikkyo (Sino-Japanese esoteric Buddhism), which helped the worship of the god Inari that had encompassed the concept of Dakiniten spread, as Shingon also spread across the country.

At Toji Temple, The god Inari merged with Dakiniten (an Indian female deity, Dakini) of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism, which helped the worship of the god Inari that had encompassed the concept of Dakiniten spread, as Shingon Sect also spread across the country.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに基づき、「真言密教」→"Shingon Esoteric Buddhism"に修正しました。また、"Shingon"→"Shingon Sect"としました。

sen.j: 荼枳尼天は人を食らう夜叉、または、羅刹の一種で、中世には霊孤と同一の存在とみなされた。
sen.e: Dakiniten had seen as a kind of yaksha (Buddhist guardian deities sometimes depicted as demonic warriors) or rakshasa (type of evil spirit), and in the middle ages, it was thought to be identical to Reiko (a creature believed to live somewhere between the human and spiritual worlds).
sen.cmt: 「霊孤」の説明を加えましたが、あまり信頼のできる場所からの情報ではありません。

sen.j: 稲の神であることから食物神の宇迦之御魂神と同一視され、後に他の食物神も習合した。
sen.e: As the god Inari is the rice god, it became associated with Ukanomitama-no-Mikoto, the food god, who later merged other food gods.

sen.j: 中世以降、工業・商業が盛んになってくると、稲荷神は農業神から工業神・商業神・屋敷神など福徳開運の万能の神ともされるようになり、農村だけでなく町家や武家にも盛んに勧請されるようになった。
sen.e: During the middle ages, where commerce and industry became more prosperous, the god Inari, who had initially been the agriculture god, became the god of all the mighty, merging the gods of commerce, industry, and residence, and was believed to bring happiness and fortunes to people; new Inari-jinja Shrines were built one after another by transferring the god Inari from a Inari-jinja Shrine not only in farming villages but also in the communities of traders and samurai.

sen.j: 明治の神仏分離の際、多くの稲荷社は宇迦之御魂神などの神話に登場する神を祀る神社になったが、一部は荼枳尼天を本尊とする寺になった。
sen.e: When the Meiji government separated Shinto and Buddhism, many Inari-jinja Shrines chose to worship gods that appear in Japanese mythology, like Ukanomitama-no-Mikoto, but some became Buddhist temples, which worship Dakiniten.

sen.j: キツネの古名を「けつ」と言い、御饌津神を「三狐神」と解して、狐が稲荷神の神使、あるいは眷属であるとされた。
sen.e: People interpreted "Miketsu no Kami" as "three fox gods" as "Mi" means 'three', "ketsu" used to mean 'fox', and "no Kami" means 'gods', causing the fox to be thought as an envoy or a relative of a deity.

sen.j: もう一つは狐神として祀られ庶民の間から派生した稲荷神である。
sen.e: The other is the god enshrined as the fox god, a god derived from a belief among common people.

sen.j: 三大稲荷
sen.e: The Three Major Inari in Japan
The Three Major Inari in Japan
The Three Major Inari in Japan

sen.j: いくつかの稲荷神社や稲荷を祀る寺院では、「当社は日本三大稲荷の一つ」ということを宣伝文句としている。
sen.e: Some Inari-jinja Shrines or Buddhist temples that worship the god Inari use the phase that "we are one of the three major Inari in Japan" for promotion.
Some Inari-jinja Shrines or Buddhist temples that worship the god Inari use the phase that "we are one of the three major Inari in Japan" for promotional purposes.
Some Inari-jinja Shrines or Buddhist temples that worship the god Inari use the phase that 'we are one of the three major Inari in Japan' for promotional purposes.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更しました。

sen.j: しかし、それらの内容は寺社によって異なっている。
sen.e: However, what they say is different from shrine to shrine or temple to temple.
However, what they say is different from shrine to shrine or temple to temple.
However, what they say is different from shrine to shrine or temple to temple.

sen.j: 『大日本史』等の歴史書や稲荷信仰事典では、総本社の伏見稲荷大社のほか祐徳稲荷神社、豊川稲荷を日本三大稲荷としている。
sen.e: According to historical writings like Dainihon-shi ("History of Great Japan") and Inarishinko-jiten ("Encyclopedia of Inari Belief"), Yutoku-inarijinjya Shrine and Toyokawa Inari are included in the three major Inari, besides Fushimi-inari-taisha Shrine, the headquarters.

According to historical writings like Dainihon-shi ("History of Great Japan") and Inarishinko-jiten ("Encyclopedia of Inari Belief"), Yutoku-inarijinjya Shrine and Toyokawa Inari are included in the three major Inari, besides Fushimi-inari-taisha Shrine, the headquarters.

According to historical writings like "Dainihon-shi" (History of Great Japan) and Inarishinko-jiten (Encyclopedia of Inari Belief), Yutoku Inari-jinja Shrine and Toyokawa Inari Temple are included in the three major Inari, besides Fushimi Inari-taisha Shrine, the headquarters.
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを本文に合わせ修正しました。豊川稲荷は寺院のため、Toyokawa Inari Templeとしました。 神社名表記を一部修正しました。

sen.j: その他の文献には笠間稲荷、竹駒神社、最上稲荷などが候補に上がる。
sen.e: Other literature lists Kasama Inari-Jinja Shrine, Takekoma-Jinja Shrine, and Saijo Inari as the candidate.
Other literature lists Kasama Inari-Jinja Shrine, Takekoma-Jinja Shrine, and Saijo Inari as candidates.
Other literature lists Kasama Inari-jinja Shrine, Takekoma-jinja Shrine, and Saijo Inari Temple as candidates.
sen.cmt: jinjaを小文字にしました。最上稲荷は寺院のため、Saijo Inari Templeとしました。

sen.j: 尤も、総本社である伏見稲荷大社では、「三大稲荷は地域により異なる」として、三大稲荷の3社を限定することはしていない。
sen.e: However, Fushimi-inari-taisha Shrine, the headquarters, say that the three major Inari are different from area to area; it has no intention to limit them to those they designate.
However, Fushimi-inari-taisha Shrine, the headquarters, say that the three major Inari are different from area to area; it has no intention to limit them to those they designate.
However, Fushimi Inari-taisha Shrine, the headquarters, say that the three major Inari are different from area to area; it has no intention to limit them to those they designate.

sen.j: しかし、これらの神社は実際、地元に深く信仰が根付いているのも事実であり、地元では決して伏見に負けない知名度である（むしろ、伏見から勧請した稲荷信仰がしっかりと根付いている）という郷土の誇りの表れと見做すこともできる。
sen.e: It is true that local shrines are well revered, worshipped, better-known by local people than Fushimi-inari-taisha Shrine, from which the god Inari has been moved; this should be regarded as evidence that Inari belief has taken deep root and become people's pride.

It is true that local shrines are well revered, worshipped, and better-known by local people than Fushimi-inari-taisha Shrines, from which the god Inari has been moved; this should be regarded as evidence that Inari belief has taken deep root and become the people's pride.

sen.j: 因みに豊川稲荷は妙厳寺という寺院であり、仏教伝来の荼枳尼天は、伏見が祭神とする宇迦之御魂神とは系統が全く異なる。
sen.e: Additionally, Toyokawa Inari is a temple named Myogon-ji Temple, which worships Buddhist Dakiniten, who is totally different from Ukanomitama-no-Mikoto enshrined in Fushimi.

sen.cmt: ハイフンを外し、Ukanomitama no Mikotoとしました。

sen.e: Among Beppyo-jinja Shrines (shrines that are under Grand Shrine at Ise, as listed in an appendix), those given ranking now are limited to the following shrines, and they may have had extraordinary power: Shiwa-inari-jinjya Shrine, Takekoma-jinja Shrine, Kasama Inari-jinja Shrine, Yakyu-inari- jinja Shrine, Taikodani-inari-jinja Shrine, Yutoku-inarijinjya Shrine, and Takahashi-jinja Shrine (additionally, it was only Fushimi-inari-taisha Shrine who had received the shrine ranking under the ex-ranking system while the rest were treated as prefectural shrines or village shrines).
